stem: A 58-year-old client is 2 days post-operative following a total knee arthroplasty. Based on the documentation, which finding is most predictive of a pulmonary embolism (PE)?

options.text: Sudden-onset tachypnea and hypoxia with clear breath sounds.

rationale.correct: The most predictive clinical cue for a pulmonary embolism (PE) in a post-operative patient is the mismatch of severe respiratory distress/tachypnea and profound hypoxia while the lungs remain clear. This occurs because the vessels are blocked, but the alveoli are still empty and clear of fluid. If it were pneumonia or heart failure, crackles or wheezes would be auscultated. Calf size difference is a cue for a deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to a PE, but the mismatch confirms the pulmonary event.
clinicalPearls: PE = Clear lungs + tachypnea + low SpO2.
V/Q Mismatch: Ventilation (V) is fine, but Perfusion (Q) is compromised.
Treatment: 1. Elevate HOB. 2. Oxygen. 3. Anticoagulation (Heparin) or Thrombolytics.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting calf size as the most predictive of PE.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Calf size predicts a DVT. The question asks what predicts the PE (the event in the lungs). Focus on the system being questioned.

mnemonic.title: P-E Mismatch
mnemonic.expansion: P-Pipes are blocked. E-Empty lungs (Clear). M-Mismatch of oxygen.

Vitals: BP 82/40. HR 142. Temp 98.6°F (37°C).
Symptoms: Client reports sudden, sharp chest pain with deep breaths (pleuritic pain) and extreme anxiety ('Impending Doom').

exhibits.title: Post-Operative Status
exhibits.content: Note: Client has not ambulated since surgery due to significant pain. Right calf is 4 cm larger than the left and is warm to the touch.
